awd_titl_txt: Spectral Properties, Cutoff, and Limit Profiles for Markov Chains
awd_abstract_narration:
Markov chains are random processes that retain no memory of the past. Over a hundred years since they were firstly introduced, the study of Markov chains is critical to mathematics, physics, computer science, statistics, engineering, and bioinformatics. This project focuses on the study of the rate of convergence of a Markov chain to the stationary distribution. The study of specific examples of Markov chains has proven to be very useful in finding deep connections between rapid mixing and spatial properties of spin systems, in sampling, approximate counting algorithms and card shuffling.

The project has five broad aims all directed towards understanding cutoff, developing old and new techniques, and on studying specific examples of Markov chains that could help develop a theory. The first program focuses on the study of random walks on random graph models via understanding their geometry. The second program concerns the study of interacting particle systems, such as the asymmetric exclusion process with open boundaries. The third program is focusing on the existence of cutoff for random walks on trees.  The fourth program concerns the properties of Glauber dynamics for the Potts model and its differences from the Ising model. The fifth program addresses several questions about the mixing properties of random walks on matrix groups and general configuration spaces that consist of matrices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A Markov chain is a standard tool to generate random objects, such as random colorings of graphs, random bases of vector spaces or random triangulations of a polygon.  The time it takes a physical system to reach equilibrium is an example of a mixing time. Mixing times are most useful for problems in mathematics, statistical physics, cryptography and theoretical computer science. Cutoff describes a phase transition; in the examples where cutoff occurs, the Markov chain starts far away from equilibrium and there is a very abrupt change where suddenly the Markov chain is very close to equilibrium. The limit profile captures limiting value of the distance to stationarity, as the size of the state space grows to infinity. This project includes nine papers, with a variety of authors including two postdocs, two graduate students and two undergraduate students, that investigated the existence of cutoff for important Markov chains and their limit profiles. 
Joint work with Gantert and Schmid initiated the study of the mixing times of the simple exclusion process with open boundaries. A susbsequent work with Schmid proves that under certain regimes the stationary measure of the asymmetric exclusion process projected onto a subinterval is close intotal variation distance to a product measure.
In this project, two techniques for studying the limit profile of a Markov chain were developed. On the first one, a comparison technique was introduced that allowed to determine the limit profile of star transpositions by arguing that it has to be the same as the limit profile of random transpositions. In joint work with Olesker--Taylor, we derive approximation lemmas for projections of random walks on groups.
In terms of random walk of groups, this project focused on card shuffling and a random walk on the group of unipotent, upper triangular matrices. The random walk on the group of $n \times n$ upper triangular matrices with entries in $Z/mZ$ of interest isgenerated by steps that add or subtract a uniformly random row to the row above. In joint work with Sly, we proved thatthe mixing time of this random walk is $O(m^2n \log n + n^2m^{o(1)})$. As far as card shuffling is concerned, in joint work with Priestley and Schmid we studied the mixing times and cutoff for the $S_k$ shuffle and in joint work with Peng we investigated the cutoff behavior for the $k$--sided transpositions.
In more general Markov chain setups, in joint work with Sarnak we prove that the non-backtracking random walk on Ramanujan graphs with large girth exhibits the fastest possible cutoff with a bounded window. Similarly, in a general combinatorial setup, in joint work with Defant and Li, we study Markov chains via rowmotion, a certain well-studied bijective operator on the distributive lattice of orderideals of a finite poset. We compute the stationary distribution of the rowmotion Markov chain of a latticeobtained by adding a minimal element and a maximal element to a disjoint union of two chains. Webound the mixing time of the general Markov chain and investigate cutoff for specific cases.
